text: After King Ahab’s death, the land of Moab rebelled against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Israel’s new king, Ahaziah, fell through the latticework of an upper room at his palace in Samaria and was seriously injured. So he sent messengers to the temple of Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron, to ask whether he would recover.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel of the Lord told Elijah, who was from Tishbe, “Go and confront the messengers of the king of Samaria and ask them, ‘Is there no God in Israel? Why are you going to Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron, to ask whether the king will recover?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, therefore, this is what the Lord says: You will never leave the bed you are lying on; you will surely die.’” So Elijah went to deliver the message.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the messengers returned to the king, he asked them, “Why have you returned so soon?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “A man came up to us and told us to go back to the king and give him this message. ‘This is what the Lord says: Is there no God in Israel? Why are you sending men to Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron, to ask whether you will recover? Therefore, because you have done this, you will never leave the bed you are lying on; you will surely die.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “What sort of man was he?” the king demanded. “What did he look like?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They replied, “He was a hairy man, and he wore a leather belt around his waist.”
“Elijah from Tishbe!” the king exclaimed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he sent an army captain with fifty soldiers to arrest him. They found him sitting on top of a hill. The captain said to him, “Man of God, the king has commanded you to come down with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elijah replied to the captain, “If I am a man of God, let fire come down from heaven and destroy you and your fifty men!” Then fire fell from heaven and killed them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king sent another captain with fifty men. The captain said to him, “Man of God, the king demands that you come down at once.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah replied, “If I am a man of God, let fire come down from heaven and destroy you and your fifty men!” And again the fire of God fell from heaven and killed them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once more the king sent a third captain with fifty men. But this time the captain went up the hill and fell to his knees before Elijah. He pleaded with him, “O man of God, please spare my life and the lives of these, your fifty servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: See how the fire from heaven came down and destroyed the first two groups. But now please spare my life!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord said to Elijah, “Go down with him, and don’t be afraid of him.” So Elijah got up and went with him to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elijah said to the king, “This is what the Lord says: Why did you send messengers to Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron, to ask whether you will recover? Is there no God in Israel to answer your question? Therefore, because you have done this, you will never leave the bed you are lying on; you will surely die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahaziah died, just as the Lord had promised through Elijah. Since Ahaziah did not have a son to succeed him, his brother Joram became the next king. This took place in the second year of the reign of Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Ahaziah’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord was about to take Elijah up to heaven in a whirlwind, Elijah and Elisha were traveling from Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Elijah said to Elisha, “Stay here, for the Lord has told me to go to Bethel.”
But Elisha replied, “As surely as the Lord lives and you yourself live, I will never leave you!” So they went down together to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The group of prophets from Bethel came to Elisha and asked him, “Did you know that the Lord is going to take your master away from you today?”
“Of course I know,” Elisha answered. “But be quiet about it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elijah said to Elisha, “Stay here, for the Lord has told me to go to Jericho.”
But Elisha replied again, “As surely as the Lord lives and you yourself live, I will never leave you.” So they went on together to Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the group of prophets from Jericho came to Elisha and asked him, “Did you know that the Lord is going to take your master away from you today?”
“Of course I know,” Elisha answered. “But be quiet about it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elijah said to Elisha, “Stay here, for the Lord has told me to go to the Jordan River.”
But again Elisha replied, “As surely as the Lord lives and you yourself live, I will never leave you.” So they went on together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fifty men from the group of prophets also went and watched from a distance as Elijah and Elisha stopped beside the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elijah folded his cloak together and struck the water with it. The river divided, and the two of them went across on dry ground!
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they came to the other side, Elijah said to Elisha, “Tell me what I can do for you before I am taken away.”
And Elisha replied, “Please let me inherit a double share of your spirit and become your successor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “You have asked a difficult thing,” Elijah replied. “If you see me when I am taken from you, then you will get your request. But if not, then you won’t.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were walking along and talking, suddenly a chariot of fire appeared, drawn by horses of fire. It drove between the two men, separating them, and Elijah was carried by a whirlwind into heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha saw it and cried out, “My father! My father! I see the chariots and charioteers of Israel!” And as they disappeared from sight, Elisha tore his clothes in distress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha picked up Elijah’s cloak, which had fallen when he was taken up. Then Elisha returned to the bank of the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck the water with Elijah’s cloak and cried out, “Where is the Lord, the God of Elijah?” Then the river divided, and Elisha went across.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the group of prophets from Jericho saw from a distance what happened, they exclaimed, “Elijah’s spirit rests upon Elisha!” And they went to meet him and bowed to the ground before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Sir,” they said, “just say the word and fifty of our strongest men will search the wilderness for your master. Perhaps the Spirit of the Lord has left him on some mountain or in some valley.”
“No,” Elisha said, “don’t send them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they kept urging him until they shamed him into agreeing, and he finally said, “All right, send them.” So fifty men searched for three days but did not find Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha was still at Jericho when they returned. “Didn’t I tell you not to go?” he asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day the leaders of the town of Jericho visited Elisha. “We have a problem, my lord,” they told him. “This town is located in pleasant surroundings, as you can see. But the water is bad, and the land is unproductive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said, “Bring me a new bowl with salt in it.” So they brought it to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went out to the spring that supplied the town with water and threw the salt into it. And he said, “This is what the Lord says: I have purified this water. It will no longer cause death or infertility.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the water has remained pure ever since, just as Elisha said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha left Jericho and went up to Bethel. As he was walking along the road, a group of boys from the town began mocking and making fun of him. “Go away, baldy!” they chanted. “Go away, baldy!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha turned around and looked at them, and he cursed them in the name of the Lord. Then two bears came out of the woods and mauled forty-two of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there Elisha went to Mount Carmel and finally returned to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab’s son Joram began to rule over Israel in the eighteenth year of King Jehoshaphat’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Samaria twelve years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the Lord’s sight, but not to the same extent as his father and mother. He at least tore down the sacred pillar of Baal that his father had set up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, he continued in the sins that Jeroboam son of Nebat had committed and led the people of Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Mesha of Moab was a sheep breeder. He used to pay the king of Israel an annual tribute of 100,000 lambs and the wool of 100,000 rams.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after Ahab’s death, the king of Moab rebelled against the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Joram promptly mustered the army of Israel and marched from Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the way, he sent this message to King Jehoshaphat of Judah: “The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you join me in battle against him?”
And Jehoshaphat replied, “Why, of course! You and I are as one. My troops are your troops, and my horses are your horses.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Jehoshaphat asked, “What route will we take?”
“We will attack from the wilderness of Edom,” Joram replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Edom and his troops joined them, and all three armies traveled along a roundabout route through the wilderness for seven days. But there was no water for the men or their animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What should we do?” the king of Israel cried out. “The Lord has brought the three of us here to let the king of Moab defeat us.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But King Jehoshaphat of Judah asked, “Is there no prophet of the Lord with us? If there is, we can ask the Lord what to do through him.”
One of King Joram’s officers replied, “Elisha son of Shaphat is here. He used to be Elijah’s personal assistant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat said, “Yes, the Lord speaks through him.” So the king of Israel, King Jehoshaphat of Judah, and the king of Edom went to consult with Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why are you coming to me?” Elisha asked the king of Israel. “Go to the pagan prophets of your father and mother!”
But King Joram of Israel said, “No! For it was the Lord who called us three kings here—only to be defeated by the king of Moab!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha replied, “As surely as the Lord Almighty lives, whom I serve, I wouldn’t even bother with you except for my respect for King Jehoshaphat of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now bring me someone who can play the harp.”
While the harp was being played, the power of the Lord came upon Elisha,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said, “This is what the Lord says: This dry valley will be filled with pools of water!
speaker: Narrator

text: You will see neither wind nor rain, says the Lord, but this valley will be filled with water. You will have plenty for yourselves and your cattle and other animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this is only a simple thing for the Lord, for he will make you victorious over the army of Moab!
speaker: Narrator

text: You will conquer the best of their towns, even the fortified ones. You will cut down all their good trees, stop up all their springs, and ruin all their good land with stones.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day at about the time when the morning sacrifice was offered, water suddenly appeared! It was flowing from the direction of Edom, and soon there was water everywhere.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, when the people of Moab heard about the three armies marching against them, they mobilized every man who was old enough to strap on a sword, and they stationed themselves along their border.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they got up the next morning, the sun was shining across the water, making it appear red to the Moabites—like blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It’s blood!” the Moabites exclaimed. “The three armies must have attacked and killed each other! Let’s go, men of Moab, and collect the plunder!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Moabites arrived at the Israelite camp, the army of Israel rushed out and attacked them until they turned and ran. The army of Israel chased them into the land of Moab, destroying everything as they went.
speaker: Narrator

text: They destroyed the towns, covered their good land with stones, stopped up all the springs, and cut down all the good trees. Finally, only Kir-hareseth and its stone walls were left, but men with slings surrounded and attacked it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Moab saw that he was losing the battle, he led 700 of his swordsmen in a desperate attempt to break through the enemy lines near the king of Edom, but they failed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Moab took his oldest son, who would have been the next king, and sacrificed him as a burnt offering on the wall. So there was great anger against Israel, and the Israelites withdrew and returned to their own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day the widow of a member of the group of prophets came to Elisha and cried out, “My husband who served you is dead, and you know how he feared the Lord. But now a creditor has come, threatening to take my two sons as slaves.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What can I do to help you?” Elisha asked. “Tell me, what do you have in the house?”
“Nothing at all, except a flask of olive oil,” she replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elisha said, “Borrow as many empty jars as you can from your friends and neighbors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then go into your house with your sons and shut the door behind you. Pour olive oil from your flask into the jars, setting each one aside when it is filled.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she did as she was told. Her sons kept bringing jars to her, and she filled one after another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Soon every container was full to the brim!
“Bring me another jar,” she said to one of her sons.
“There aren’t any more!” he told her. And then the olive oil stopped flowing.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she told the man of God what had happened, he said to her, “Now sell the olive oil and pay your debts, and you and your sons can live on what is left over.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Elisha went to the town of Shunem. A wealthy woman lived there, and she urged him to come to her home for a meal. After that, whenever he passed that way, he would stop there for something to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to her husband, “I am sure this man who stops in from time to time is a holy man of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s build a small room for him on the roof and furnish it with a bed, a table, a chair, and a lamp. Then he will have a place to stay whenever he comes by.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Elisha returned to Shunem, and he went up to this upper room to rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his servant Gehazi, “Tell the woman from Shunem I want to speak to her.” When she appeared,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elisha said to Gehazi, “Tell her, ‘We appreciate the kind concern you have shown us. What can we do for you? Can we put in a good word for you to the king or to the commander of the army?’”
“No,” she replied, “my family takes good care of me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Later Elisha asked Gehazi, “What can we do for her?”
Gehazi replied, “She doesn’t have a son, and her husband is an old man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Call her back again,” Elisha told him. When the woman returned, Elisha said to her as she stood in the doorway,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Next year at this time you will be holding a son in your arms!”
“No, my lord!” she cried. “O man of God, don’t deceive me and get my hopes up like that.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But sure enough, the woman soon became pregnant. And at that time the following year she had a son, just as Elisha had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day when her child was older, he went out to help his father, who was working with the harvesters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Suddenly he cried out, “My head hurts! My head hurts!”
His father said to one of the servants, “Carry him home to his mother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servant took him home, and his mother held him on her lap. But around noontime he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: She carried him up and laid him on the bed of the man of God, then shut the door and left him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: She sent a message to her husband: “Send one of the servants and a donkey so that I can hurry to the man of God and come right back.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why go today?” he asked. “It is neither a new moon festival nor a Sabbath.”
But she said, “It will be all right.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she saddled the donkey and said to the servant, “Hurry! Don’t slow down unless I tell you to.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As she approached the man of God at Mount Carmel, Elisha saw her in the distance. He said to Gehazi, “Look, the woman from Shunem is coming.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Run out to meet her and ask her, ‘Is everything all right with you, your husband, and your child?’”
“Yes,” the woman told Gehazi, “everything is fine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when she came to the man of God at the mountain, she fell to the ground before him and caught hold of his feet. Gehazi began to push her away, but the man of God said, “Leave her alone. She is deeply troubled, but the Lord has not told me what it is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said, “Did I ask you for a son, my lord? And didn’t I say, ‘Don’t deceive me and get my hopes up’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said to Gehazi, “Get ready to travel; take my staff and go! Don’t talk to anyone along the way. Go quickly and lay the staff on the child’s face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the boy’s mother said, “As surely as the Lord lives and you yourself live, I won’t go home unless you go with me.” So Elisha returned with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gehazi hurried on ahead and laid the staff on the child’s face, but nothing happened. There was no sign of life. He returned to meet Elisha and told him, “The child is still dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elisha arrived, the child was indeed dead, lying there on the prophet’s bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went in alone and shut the door behind him and prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he lay down on the child’s body, placing his mouth on the child’s mouth, his eyes on the child’s eyes, and his hands on the child’s hands. And as he stretched out on him, the child’s body began to grow warm again!
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha got up, walked back and forth across the room once, and then stretched himself out again on the child. This time the boy sneezed seven times and opened his eyes!
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha summoned Gehazi. “Call the child’s mother!” he said. And when she came in, Elisha said, “Here, take your son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: She fell at his feet and bowed before him, overwhelmed with gratitude. Then she took her son in her arms and carried him downstairs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha now returned to Gilgal, and there was a famine in the land. One day as the group of prophets was seated before him, he said to his servant, “Put a large pot on the fire, and make some stew for the rest of the group.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of the young men went out into the field to gather herbs and came back with a pocketful of wild gourds. He shredded them and put them into the pot without realizing they were poisonous.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the stew was served to the men. But after they had eaten a bite or two they cried out, “Man of God, there’s poison in this stew!” So they would not eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha said, “Bring me some flour.” Then he threw it into the pot and said, “Now it’s all right; go ahead and eat.” And then it did not harm them.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day a man from Baal-shalishah brought the man of God a sack of fresh grain and twenty loaves of barley bread made from the first grain of his harvest. Elisha said, “Give it to the people so they can eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What?” his servant exclaimed. “Feed a hundred people with only this?”
But Elisha repeated, “Give it to the people so they can eat, for this is what the Lord says: Everyone will eat, and there will even be some left over!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they gave it to the people, there was plenty for all and some left over, just as the Lord had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Aram had great admiration for Naaman, the commander of his army, because through him the Lord had given Aram great victories. But though Naaman was a mighty warrior, he suffered from leprosy.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this time Aramean raiders had invaded the land of Israel, and among their captives was a young girl who had been given to Naaman’s wife as a maid.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day the girl said to her mistress, “I wish my master would go to see the prophet in Samaria. He would heal him of his leprosy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Naaman told the king what the young girl from Israel had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and visit the prophet,” the king of Aram told him. “I will send a letter of introduction for you to take to the king of Israel.” So Naaman started out, carrying as gifts 750 pounds of silver, 150 pounds of gold, and ten sets of clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: The letter to the king of Israel said: “With this letter I present my servant Naaman. I want you to heal him of his leprosy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Israel read the letter, he tore his clothes in dismay and said, “Am I God, that I can give life and take it away? Why is this man asking me to heal someone with leprosy? I can see that he’s just trying to pick a fight with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Elisha, the man of God, heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes in dismay, he sent this message to him: “Why are you so upset? Send Naaman to me, and he will learn that there is a true prophet here in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Naaman went with his horses and chariots and waited at the door of Elisha’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elisha sent a messenger out to him with this message: “Go and wash yourself seven times in the Jordan River. Then your skin will be restored, and you will be healed of your leprosy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Naaman became angry and stalked away. “I thought he would certainly come out to meet me!” he said. “I expected him to wave his hand over the leprosy and call on the name of the Lord his God and heal me!
speaker: Narrator

text: Aren’t the rivers of Damascus, the Abana and the Pharpar, better than any of the rivers of Israel? Why shouldn’t I wash in them and be healed?” So Naaman turned and went away in a rage.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his officers tried to reason with him and said, “Sir, if the prophet had told you to do something very difficult, wouldn’t you have done it? So you should certainly obey him when he says simply, ‘Go and wash and be cured!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Naaman went down to the Jordan River and dipped himself seven times, as the man of God had instructed him. And his skin became as healthy as the skin of a young child, and he was healed!
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Naaman and his entire party went back to find the man of God. They stood before him, and Naaman said, “Now I know that there is no God in all the world except in Israel. So please accept a gift from your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elisha replied, “As surely as the Lord lives, whom I serve, I will not accept any gifts.” And though Naaman urged him to take the gift, Elisha refused.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Naaman said, “All right, but please allow me to load two of my mules with earth from this place, and I will take it back home with me. From now on I will never again offer burnt offerings or sacrifices to any other god except the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, may the Lord pardon me in this one thing: When my master the king goes into the temple of the god Rimmon to worship there and leans on my arm, may the Lord pardon me when I bow, too.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go in peace,” Elisha said. So Naaman started home again.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Gehazi, the servant of Elisha, the man of God, said to himself, “My master should not have let this Aramean get away without accepting any of his gifts. As surely as the Lord lives, I will chase after him and get something from him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Gehazi set off after Naaman.
When Naaman saw Gehazi running after him, he climbed down from his chariot and went to meet him. “Is everything all right?” Naaman asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yes,” Gehazi said, “but my master has sent me to tell you that two young prophets from the hill country of Ephraim have just arrived. He would like 75 pounds of silver and two sets of clothing to give to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “By all means, take twice as much silver,” Naaman insisted. He gave him two sets of clothing, tied up the money in two bags, and sent two of his servants to carry the gifts for Gehazi.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they arrived at the citadel, Gehazi took the gifts from the servants and sent the men back. Then he went and hid the gifts inside the house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he went in to his master, Elisha asked him, “Where have you been, Gehazi?”
“I haven’t been anywhere,” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elisha asked him, “Don’t you realize that I was there in spirit when Naaman stepped down from his chariot to meet you? Is this the time to receive money and clothing, olive groves and vineyards, sheep and cattle, and male and female servants?
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you have done this, you and your descendants will suffer from Naaman’s leprosy forever.” When Gehazi left the room, he was covered with leprosy; his skin was white as snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day the group of prophets came to Elisha and told him, “As you can see, this place where we meet with you is too small.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let’s go down to the Jordan River, where there are plenty of logs. There we can build a new place for us to meet.”
“All right,” he told them, “go ahead.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Please come with us,” someone suggested.
“I will,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he went with them.
When they arrived at the Jordan, they began cutting down trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as one of them was cutting a tree, his ax head fell into the river. “Oh, sir!” he cried. “It was a borrowed ax!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Where did it fall?” the man of God asked. When he showed him the place, Elisha cut a stick and threw it into the water at that spot. Then the ax head floated to the surface.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Grab it,” Elisha said. And the man reached out and grabbed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Aram was at war with Israel, he would confer with his officers and say, “We will mobilize our forces at such and such a place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But immediately Elisha, the man of God, would warn the king of Israel, “Do not go near that place, for the Arameans are planning to mobilize their troops there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel would send word to the place indicated by the man of God. Time and again Elisha warned the king, so that he would be on the alert there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Aram became very upset over this. He called his officers together and demanded, “Which of you is the traitor? Who has been informing the king of Israel of my plans?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “It’s not us, my lord the king,” one of the officers replied. “Elisha, the prophet in Israel, tells the king of Israel even the words you speak in the privacy of your bedroom!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Go and find out where he is,” the king commanded, “so I can send troops to seize him.”
And the report came back: “Elisha is at Dothan.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So one night the king of Aram sent a great army with many chariots and horses to surround the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the servant of the man of God got up early the next morning and went outside, there were troops, horses, and chariots everywhere. “Oh, sir, what will we do now?” the young man cried to Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t be afraid!” Elisha told him. “For there are more on our side than on theirs!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha prayed, “O Lord, open his eyes and let him see!” The Lord opened the young man’s eyes, and when he looked up, he saw that the hillside around Elisha was filled with horses and chariots of fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Aramean army advanced toward him, Elisha prayed, “O Lord, please make them blind.” So the Lord struck them with blindness as Elisha had asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha went out and told them, “You have come the wrong way! This isn’t the right city! Follow me, and I will take you to the man you are looking for.” And he led them to the city of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as they had entered Samaria, Elisha prayed, “O Lord, now open their eyes and let them see.” So the Lord opened their eyes, and they discovered that they were in the middle of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Israel saw them, he shouted to Elisha, “My father, should I kill them? Should I kill them?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Of course not!” Elisha replied. “Do we kill prisoners of war? Give them food and drink and send them home again to their master.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king made a great feast for them and then sent them home to their master. After that, the Aramean raiders stayed away from the land of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, however, King Ben-hadad of Aram mustered his entire army and besieged Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, there was a great famine in the city. The siege lasted so long that a donkey’s head sold for eighty pieces of silver, and a cup of dove’s dung sold for five pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day as the king of Israel was walking along the wall of the city, a woman called to him, “Please help me, my lord the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He answered, “If the Lord doesn’t help you, what can I do? I have neither food from the threshing floor nor wine from the press to give you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But then the king asked, “What is the matter?”
She replied, “This woman said to me: ‘Come on, let’s eat your son today, then we will eat my son tomorrow.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So we cooked my son and ate him. Then the next day I said to her, ‘Kill your son so we can eat him,’ but she has hidden her son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard this, he tore his clothes in despair. And as the king walked along the wall, the people could see that he was wearing burlap under his robe next to his skin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “May God strike me and even kill me if I don’t separate Elisha’s head from his shoulders this very day,” the king vowed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha was sitting in his house with the elders of Israel when the king sent a messenger to summon him. But before the messenger arrived, Elisha said to the elders, “A murderer has sent a man to cut off my head. When he arrives, shut the door and keep him out. We will soon hear his master’s steps following him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Elisha was still saying this, the messenger arrived. And the king said, “All this misery is from the Lord! Why should I wait for the Lord any longer?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha replied, “Listen to this message from the Lord! This is what the Lord says: By this time tomorrow in the markets of Samaria, six quarts of choice flour will cost only one piece of silver, and twelve quarts of barley grain will cost only one piece of silver.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The officer assisting the king said to the man of God, “That couldn’t happen even if the Lord opened the windows of heaven!”
But Elisha replied, “You will see it happen with your own eyes, but you won’t be able to eat any of it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there were four men with leprosy sitting at the entrance of the city gates. “Why should we sit here waiting to die?” they asked each other.
speaker: Narrator

text: “We will starve if we stay here, but with the famine in the city, we will starve if we go back there. So we might as well go out and surrender to the Aramean army. If they let us live, so much the better. But if they kill us, we would have died anyway.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So at twilight they set out for the camp of the Arameans. But when they came to the edge of the camp, no one was there!
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had caused the Aramean army to hear the clatter of speeding chariots and the galloping of horses and the sounds of a great army approaching. “The king of Israel has hired the Hittites and Egyptians to attack us!” they cried to one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they panicked and ran into the night, abandoning their tents, horses, donkeys, and everything else, as they fled for their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men with leprosy arrived at the edge of the camp, they went into one tent after another, eating and drinking wine; and they carried off silver and gold and clothing and hid it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, they said to each other, “This is not right. This is a day of good news, and we aren’t sharing it with anyone! If we wait until morning, some calamity will certainly fall upon us. Come on, let’s go back and tell the people at the palace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they went back to the city and told the gatekeepers what had happened. “We went out to the Aramean camp,” they said, “and no one was there! The horses and donkeys were tethered and the tents were all in order, but there wasn’t a single person around!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the gatekeepers shouted the news to the people in the palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king got out of bed in the middle of the night and told his officers, “I know what has happened. The Arameans know we are starving, so they have left their camp and have hidden in the fields. They are expecting us to leave the city, and then they will take us alive and capture the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of his officers replied, “We had better send out scouts to check into this. Let them take five of the remaining horses. If something happens to them, it will be no worse than if they stay here and die with the rest of us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So two chariots with horses were prepared, and the king sent scouts to see what had happened to the Aramean army.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went all the way to the Jordan River, following a trail of clothing and equipment that the Arameans had thrown away in their mad rush to escape. The scouts returned and told the king about it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Samaria rushed out and plundered the Aramean camp. So it was true that six quarts of choice flour were sold that day for one piece of silver, and twelve quarts of barley grain were sold for one piece of silver, just as the Lord had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king appointed his officer to control the traffic at the gate, but he was knocked down and trampled to death as the people rushed out.
So everything happened exactly as the man of God had predicted when the king came to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man of God had said to the king, “By this time tomorrow in the markets of Samaria, six quarts of choice flour will cost one piece of silver, and twelve quarts of barley grain will cost one piece of silver.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king’s officer had replied, “That couldn’t happen even if the Lord opened the windows of heaven!” And the man of God had said, “You will see it happen with your own eyes, but you won’t be able to eat any of it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And so it was, for the people trampled him to death at the gate!
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha had told the woman whose son he had brought back to life, “Take your family and move to some other place, for the Lord has called for a famine on Israel that will last for seven years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the woman did as the man of God instructed. She took her family and settled in the land of the Philistines for seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the famine ended she returned from the land of the Philistines, and she went to see the king about getting back her house and land.
speaker: Narrator

text: As she came in, the king was talking with Gehazi, the servant of the man of God. The king had just said, “Tell me some stories about the great things Elisha has done.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Gehazi was telling the king about the time Elisha had brought a boy back to life. At that very moment, the mother of the boy walked in to make her appeal to the king about her house and land.
“Look, my lord the king!” Gehazi exclaimed. “Here is the woman now, and this is her son—the very one Elisha brought back to life!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Is this true?” the king asked her. And she told him the story. So he directed one of his officials to see that everything she had lost was restored to her, including the value of any crops that had been harvested during her absence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha went to Damascus, the capital of Aram, where King Ben-hadad lay sick. When someone told the king that the man of God had come,
speaker: Narrator

text: the king said to Hazael, “Take a gift to the man of God. Then tell him to ask the Lord, ‘Will I recover from this illness?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hazael loaded down forty camels with the finest products of Damascus as a gift for Elisha. He went to him and said, “Your servant Ben-hadad, the king of Aram, has sent me to ask, ‘Will I recover from this illness?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elisha replied, “Go and tell him, ‘You will surely recover.’ But actually the Lord has shown me that he will surely die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha stared at Hazael with a fixed gaze until Hazael became uneasy. Then the man of God started weeping.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What’s the matter, my lord?” Hazael asked him.
Elisha replied, “I know the terrible things you will do to the people of Israel. You will burn their fortified cities, kill their young men with the sword, dash their little children to the ground, and rip open their pregnant women!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hazael responded, “How could a nobody like me ever accomplish such great things?”
Elisha answered, “The Lord has shown me that you are going to be the king of Aram.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Hazael left Elisha and went back, the king asked him, “What did Elisha tell you?”
And Hazael replied, “He told me that you will surely recover.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the next day Hazael took a blanket, soaked it in water, and held it over the king’s face until he died. Then Hazael became the next king of Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram son of King Jehoshaphat of Judah began to rule over Judah in the fifth year of the reign of Joram son of Ahab, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoram followed the example of the kings of Israel and was as wicked as King Ahab, for he had married one of Ahab’s daughters. So Jehoram did what was evil in the Lord’s sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord did not want to destroy Judah, for he had promised his servant David that his descendants would continue to rule, shining like a lamp forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: During Jehoram’s reign, the Edomites revolted against Judah and crowned their own king.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoram went with all his chariots to attack the town of Zair. The Edomites surrounded him and his chariot commanders, but he went out at night and attacked them under cover of darkness. But Jehoram’s army deserted him and fled to their homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Edom has been independent from Judah to this day. The town of Libnah also revolted about that same time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Jehoram’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehoram died, he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. Then his son Ahaziah became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah son of Jehoram began to rule over Judah in the twelfth year of the reign of Joram son of Ahab, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem one year. His mother was Athaliah, a granddaughter of King Omri of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah followed the evil example of King Ahab’s family. He did what was evil in the Lord’s sight, just as Ahab’s family had done, for he was related by marriage to the family of Ahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah joined Joram son of Ahab in his war against King Hazael of Aram at Ramoth-gilead. When the Arameans wounded King Joram in the battle,
speaker: Narrator

text: he returned to Jezreel to recover from the wounds he had received at Ramoth. Because Joram was wounded, King Ahaziah of Judah went to Jezreel to visit him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Elisha the prophet had summoned a member of the group of prophets. “Get ready to travel,” he told him, “and take this flask of olive oil with you. Go to Ramoth-gilead,
speaker: Narrator

text: and find Jehu son of Jehoshaphat, son of Nimshi. Call him into a private room away from his friends,
speaker: Narrator

text: and pour the oil over his head. Say to him, ‘This is what the Lord says: I anoint you to be the king over Israel.’ Then open the door and run for your life!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the young prophet did as he was told and went to Ramoth-gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he arrived there, he found Jehu sitting around with the other army officers. “I have a message for you, Commander,” he said.
“For which one of us?” Jehu asked.
“For you, Commander,” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu left the others and went into the house. Then the young prophet poured the oil over Jehu’s head and said, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: I anoint you king over the Lord’s people, Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to destroy the family of Ahab, your master. In this way, I will avenge the murder of my prophets and all the Lord’s servants who were killed by Jezebel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire family of Ahab must be wiped out. I will destroy every one of his male descendants, slave and free alike, anywhere in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will destroy the family of Ahab as I destroyed the families of Jeroboam son of Nebat and of Baasha son of Ahijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dogs will eat Ahab’s wife Jezebel at the plot of land in Jezreel, and no one will bury her.” Then the young prophet opened the door and ran.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jehu went back to his fellow officers, and one of them asked him, “What did that madman want? Is everything all right?”
“You know how a man like that babbles on,” Jehu replied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You’re hiding something,” they said. “Tell us.”
So Jehu told them, “He said to me, ‘This is what the Lord says: I have anointed you to be king over Israel.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they quickly spread out their cloaks on the bare steps and blew the ram’s horn, shouting, “Jehu is king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu son of Jehoshaphat, son of Nimshi, led a conspiracy against King Joram. (Now Joram had been with the army at Ramoth-gilead, defending Israel against the forces of King Hazael of Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Joram was wounded in the fighting and returned to Jezreel to recover from his wounds.) So Jehu told the men with him, “If you want me to be king, don’t let anyone leave town and go to Jezreel to report what we have done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu got into a chariot and rode to Jezreel to find King Joram, who was lying there wounded. King Ahaziah of Judah was there, too, for he had gone to visit him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchman on the tower of Jezreel saw Jehu and his company approaching, so he shouted to Joram, “I see a company of troops coming!”
“Send out a rider to ask if they are coming in peace,” King Joram ordered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So a horseman went out to meet Jehu and said, “The king wants to know if you are coming in peace.”
Jehu replied, “What do you know about peace? Fall in behind me!”
The watchman called out to the king, “The messenger has met them, but he’s not returning.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the king sent out a second horseman. He rode up to them and said, “The king wants to know if you come in peace.”
Again Jehu answered, “What do you know about peace? Fall in behind me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The watchman exclaimed, “The messenger has met them, but he isn’t returning either! It must be Jehu son of Nimshi, for he’s driving like a madman.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Quick! Get my chariot ready!” King Joram commanded.
Then King Joram of Israel and King Ahaziah of Judah rode out in their chariots to meet Jehu. They met him at the plot of land that had belonged to Naboth of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
King Joram demanded, “Do you come in peace, Jehu?”
Jehu replied, “How can there be peace as long as the idolatry and witchcraft of your mother, Jezebel, are all around us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Joram turned the horses around and fled, shouting to King Ahaziah, “Treason, Ahaziah!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehu drew his bow and shot Joram between the shoulders. The arrow pierced his heart, and he sank down dead in his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu said to Bidkar, his officer, “Throw him into the plot of land that belonged to Naboth of Jezreel. Do you remember when you and I were riding along behind his father, Ahab? The Lord pronounced this message against him:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I solemnly swear that I will repay him here on this plot of land, says the Lord, for the murder of Naboth and his sons that I saw yesterday.’ So throw him out on Naboth’s property, just as the Lord said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Ahaziah of Judah saw what was happening, he fled along the road to Beth-haggan. Jehu rode after him, shouting, “Shoot him, too!” So they shot Ahaziah in his chariot at the Ascent of Gur, near Ibleam. He was able to go on as far as Megiddo, but he died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants took him by chariot to Jerusalem, where they buried him with his ancestors in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah had become king over Judah in the eleventh year of the reign of Joram son of Ahab.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jezebel, the queen mother, heard that Jehu had come to Jezreel, she painted her eyelids and fixed her hair and sat at a window.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehu entered the gate of the palace, she shouted at him, “Have you come in peace, you murderer? You’re just like Zimri, who murdered his master!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu looked up and saw her at the window and shouted, “Who is on my side?” And two or three eunuchs looked out at him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Throw her down!” Jehu yelled. So they threw her out the window, and her blood spattered against the wall and on the horses. And Jehu trampled her body under his horses’ hooves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu went into the palace and ate and drank. Afterward he said, “Someone go and bury this cursed woman, for she is the daughter of a king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they went out to bury her, they found only her skull, her feet, and her hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they returned and told Jehu, he stated, “This fulfills the message from the Lord, which he spoke through his servant Elijah from Tishbe: ‘At the plot of land in Jezreel, dogs will eat Jezebel’s body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her remains will be scattered like dung on the plot of land in Jezreel, so that no one will be able to recognize her.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab had seventy sons living in the city of Samaria. So Jehu wrote letters and sent them to Samaria, to the elders and officials of the city, and to the guardians of King Ahab’s sons. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The king’s sons are with you, and you have at your disposal chariots, horses, a fortified city, and weapons. As soon as you receive this letter,
speaker: Narrator

text: select the best qualified of your master’s sons to be your king, and prepare to fight for Ahab’s dynasty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they were paralyzed with fear and said, “We’ve seen that two kings couldn’t stand against this man! What can we do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the palace and city administrators, together with the elders and the guardians of the king’s sons, sent this message to Jehu: “We are your servants and will do anything you tell us. We will not make anyone king; do whatever you think is best.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu responded with a second letter: “If you are on my side and are going to obey me, bring the heads of your master’s sons to me at Jezreel by this time tomorrow.” Now the seventy sons of the king were being cared for by the leaders of Samaria, where they had been raised since childhood.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the letter arrived, the leaders killed all seventy of the king’s sons. They placed their heads in baskets and presented them to Jehu at Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A messenger went to Jehu and said, “They have brought the heads of the king’s sons.”
So Jehu ordered, “Pile them in two heaps at the entrance of the city gate, and leave them there until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning he went out and spoke to the crowd that had gathered around them. “You are not to blame,” he told them. “I am the one who conspired against my master and killed him. But who killed all these?
speaker: Narrator

text: You can be sure that the message of the Lord that was spoken concerning Ahab’s family will not fail. The Lord declared through his servant Elijah that this would happen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu killed all who were left of Ahab’s relatives living in Jezreel and all his important officials, his personal friends, and his priests. So Ahab was left without a single survivor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu set out for Samaria. Along the way, while he was at Beth-eked of the Shepherds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he met some relatives of King Ahaziah of Judah. “Who are you?” he asked them.
And they replied, “We are relatives of King Ahaziah. We are going to visit the sons of King Ahab and the sons of the queen mother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take them alive!” Jehu shouted to his men. And they captured all forty-two of them and killed them at the well of Beth-eked. None of them escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Jehu left there, he met Jehonadab son of Recab, who was coming to meet him. After they had greeted each other, Jehu said to him, “Are you as loyal to me as I am to you?”
“Yes, I am,” Jehonadab replied.
“If you are,” Jehu said, “then give me your hand.” So Jehonadab put out his hand, and Jehu helped him into the chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu said, “Now come with me, and see how devoted I am to the Lord.” So Jehonadab rode along with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehu arrived in Samaria, he killed everyone who was left there from Ahab’s family, just as the Lord had promised through Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu called a meeting of all the people of the city and said to them, “Ahab’s worship of Baal was nothing compared to the way I will worship him!
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, summon all the prophets and worshipers of Baal, and call together all his priests. See to it that every one of them comes, for I am going to offer a great sacrifice to Baal. Anyone who fails to come will be put to death.” But Jehu’s cunning plan was to destroy all the worshipers of Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu ordered, “Prepare a solemn assembly to worship Baal!” So they did.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent messengers throughout all Israel summoning those who worshiped Baal. They all came—not a single one remained behind—and they filled the temple of Baal from one end to the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehu instructed the keeper of the wardrobe, “Be sure that every worshiper of Baal wears one of these robes.” So robes were given to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu went into the temple of Baal with Jehonadab son of Recab. Jehu said to the worshipers of Baal, “Make sure no one who worships the Lord is here—only those who worship Baal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they were all inside the temple to offer sacrifices and burnt offerings. Now Jehu had stationed eighty of his men outside the building and had warned them, “If you let anyone escape, you will pay for it with your own life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Jehu had finished sacrificing the burnt offering, he commanded his guards and officers, “Go in and kill all of them. Don’t let a single one escape!” So they killed them all with their swords, and the guards and officers dragged their bodies outside. Then Jehu’s men went into the innermost fortress of the temple of Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: They dragged out the sacred pillar used in the worship of Baal and burned it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They smashed the sacred pillar and wrecked the temple of Baal, converting it into a public toilet, as it remains to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way, Jehu destroyed every trace of Baal worship from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not, however, destroy the gold calves at Bethel and Dan, with which Jeroboam son of Nebat had caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nonetheless the Lord said to Jehu, “You have done well in following my instructions to destroy the family of Ahab. Therefore, your descendants will be kings of Israel down to the fourth generation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehu did not obey the Law of the Lord, the God of Israel, with all his heart. He refused to turn from the sins that Jeroboam had led Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: At about that time the Lord began to cut down the size of Israel’s territory. King Hazael conquered several sections of the country
speaker: Narrator

text: east of the Jordan River, including all of Gilead, Gad, Reuben, and Manasseh. He conquered the area from the town of Aroer by the Arnon Gorge to as far north as Gilead and Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Jehu’s reign—everything he did and all his achievements—are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehu died, he was buried in Samaria. Then his son Jehoahaz became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all, Jehu reigned over Israel from Samaria for twenty-eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Athaliah, the mother of King Ahaziah of Judah, learned that her son was dead, she began to destroy the rest of the royal family.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Ahaziah’s sister Jehosheba, the daughter of King Jehoram, took Ahaziah’s infant son, Joash, and stole him away from among the rest of the king’s children, who were about to be killed. She put Joash and his nurse in a bedroom, and they hid him from Athaliah, so the child was not murdered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joash remained hidden in the Temple of the Lord for six years while Athaliah ruled over the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh year of Athaliah’s reign, Jehoiada the priest summoned the commanders, the Carite mercenaries, and the palace guards to come to the Temple of the Lord. He made a solemn pact with them and made them swear an oath of loyalty there in the Lord’s Temple; then he showed them the king’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada told them, “This is what you must do. A third of you who are on duty on the Sabbath are to guard the royal palace itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Another third of you are to stand guard at the Sur Gate. And the final third must stand guard behind the palace guard. These three groups will all guard the palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: The other two units who are off duty on the Sabbath must stand guard for the king at the Lord’s Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Form a bodyguard around the king and keep your weapons in hand. Kill anyone who tries to break through. Stay with the king wherever he goes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the commanders did everything as Jehoiada the priest ordered. The commanders took charge of the men reporting for duty that Sabbath, as well as those who were going off duty. They brought them all to Jehoiada the priest,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he supplied them with the spears and small shields that had once belonged to King David and were stored in the Temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The palace guards stationed themselves around the king, with their weapons ready. They formed a line from the south side of the Temple around to the north side and all around the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoiada brought out Joash, the king’s son, placed the crown on his head, and presented him with a copy of God’s laws. They anointed him and proclaimed him king, and everyone clapped their hands and shouted, “Long live the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Athaliah heard the noise made by the palace guards and the people, she hurried to the Lord’s Temple to see what was happening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she arrived, she saw the newly crowned king standing in his place of authority by the pillar, as was the custom at times of coronation. The commanders and trumpeters were surrounding him, and people from all over the land were rejoicing and blowing trumpets. When Athaliah saw all this, she tore her clothes in despair and shouted, “Treason! Treason!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoiada the priest ordered the commanders who were in charge of the troops, “Take her to the soldiers in front of the Temple, and kill anyone who tries to rescue her.” For the priest had said, “She must not be killed in the Temple of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they seized her and led her out to the gate where horses enter the palace grounds, and she was killed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoiada made a covenant between the Lord and the king and the people that they would be the Lord’s people. He also made a covenant between the king and the people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And all the people of the land went over to the temple of Baal and tore it down. They demolished the altars and smashed the idols to pieces, and they killed Mattan the priest of Baal in front of the altars.
Jehoiada the priest stationed guards at the Temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the commanders, the Carite mercenaries, the palace guards, and all the people of the land escorted the king from the Temple of the Lord. They went through the gate of the guards and into the palace, and the king took his seat on the royal throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people of the land rejoiced, and the city was peaceful because Athaliah had been killed at the king’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joash was seven years old when he became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joash began to rule over Judah in the seventh year of King Jehu’s reign in Israel. He reigned in Jerusalem forty years. His mother was Zibiah from Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: All his life Joash did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight because Jehoiada the priest instructed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet even so, he did not destroy the pagan shrines, and the people still offered sacrifices and burned incense there.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day King Joash said to the priests, “Collect all the money brought as a sacred offering to the Lord’s Temple, whether it is a regular assessment, a payment of vows, or a voluntary gift.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the priests take some of that money to pay for whatever repairs are needed at the Temple.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But by the twenty-third year of Joash’s reign, the priests still had not repaired the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Joash called for Jehoiada and the other priests and asked them, “Why haven’t you repaired the Temple? Don’t use any more money for your own needs. From now on, it must all be spent on Temple repairs.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priests agreed not to accept any more money from the people, and they also agreed to let others take responsibility for repairing the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoiada the priest bored a hole in the lid of a large chest and set it on the right-hand side of the altar at the entrance of the Temple of the Lord. The priests guarding the entrance put all of the people’s contributions into the chest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the chest became full, the court secretary and the high priest counted the money that had been brought to the Lord’s Temple and put it into bags.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they gave the money to the construction supervisors, who used it to pay the people working on the Lord’s Temple—the carpenters, the builders,
speaker: Narrator

text: the masons, and the stonecutters. They also used the money to buy the timber and the finished stone needed for repairing the Lord’s Temple, and they paid any other expenses related to the Temple’s restoration.
speaker: Narrator

text: The money brought to the Temple was not used for making silver bowls, lamp snuffers, basins, trumpets, or other articles of gold or silver for the Temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was paid to the workmen, who used it for the Temple repairs.
speaker: Narrator

text: No accounting of this money was required from the construction supervisors, because they were honest and trustworthy men.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the money that was contributed for guilt offerings and sin offerings was not brought into the Lord’s Temple. It was given to the priests for their own use.
speaker: Narrator

text: About this time King Hazael of Aram went to war against Gath and captured it. Then he turned to attack Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Joash collected all the sacred objects that Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, and Ahaziah, the previous kings of Judah, had dedicated, along with what he himself had dedicated. He sent them all to Hazael, along with all the gold in the treasuries of the Lord’s Temple and the royal palace. So Hazael called off his attack on Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Joash’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joash’s officers plotted against him and assassinated him at Beth-millo on the road to Silla.
speaker: Narrator

text: The assassins were Jozacar son of Shimeath and Jehozabad son of Shomer—both trusted advisers. Joash was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. Then his son Amaziah became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoahaz son of Jehu began to rule over Israel in the twenty-third year of King Joash’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Samaria seventeen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did what was evil in the Lord’s sight. He followed the example of Jeroboam son of Nebat, continuing the sins that Jeroboam had led Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord was very angry with Israel, and he allowed King Hazael of Aram and his son Ben-hadad to defeat them repeatedly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoahaz prayed for the Lord’s help, and the Lord heard his prayer, for he could see how severely the king of Aram was oppressing Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord provided someone to rescue the Israelites from the tyranny of the Arameans. Then Israel lived in safety again as they had in former days.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they continued to sin, following the evil example of Jeroboam. They also allowed the Asherah pole in Samaria to remain standing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Finally, Jehoahaz’s army was reduced to 50 charioteers, 10 chariots, and 10,000 foot soldiers. The king of Aram had killed the others, trampling them like dust under his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Jehoahaz’s reign—everything he did and the extent of his power—are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehoahaz died, he was buried in Samaria. Then his son Jehoash became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash son of Jehoahaz began to rule over Israel in the thirty-seventh year of King Joash’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Samaria sixteen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did what was evil in the Lord’s sight. He refused to turn from the sins that Jeroboam son of Nebat had led Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Jehoash’s reign and everything he did, including the extent of his power and his war with King Amaziah of Judah, are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehoash died, he was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel. Then his son Jeroboam II became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elisha was in his last illness, King Jehoash of Israel visited him and wept over him. “My father! My father! I see the chariots and charioteers of Israel!” he cried.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha told him, “Get a bow and some arrows.” And the king did as he was told.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha told him, “Put your hand on the bow,” and Elisha laid his own hands on the king’s hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he commanded, “Open that eastern window,” and he opened it. Then he said, “Shoot!” So he shot an arrow. Elisha proclaimed, “This is the Lord’s arrow, an arrow of victory over Aram, for you will completely conquer the Arameans at Aphek.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Now pick up the other arrows and strike them against the ground.” So the king picked them up and struck the ground three times.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man of God was angry with him. “You should have struck the ground five or six times!” he exclaimed. “Then you would have beaten Aram until it was entirely destroyed. Now you will be victorious only three times.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Elisha died and was buried.
Groups of Moabite raiders used to invade the land each spring.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once when some Israelites were burying a man, they spied a band of these raiders. So they hastily threw the corpse into the tomb of Elisha and fled. But as soon as the body touched Elisha’s bones, the dead man revived and jumped to his feet!
speaker: Narrator

text: King Hazael of Aram had oppressed Israel during the entire reign of King Jehoahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was gracious and merciful to the people of Israel, and they were not totally destroyed. He pitied them because of his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. And to this day he still has not completely destroyed them or banished them from his presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Hazael of Aram died, and his son Ben-hadad became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoash son of Jehoahaz recaptured from Ben-hadad son of Hazael the towns that had been taken from Jehoash’s father, Jehoahaz. Jehoash defeated Ben-hadad on three occasions, and he recovered the Israelite towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amaziah son of Joash began to rule over Judah in the second year of the reign of King Jehoash of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amaziah was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem twenty-nine years. His mother was Jehoaddin from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amaziah did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight, but not like his ancestor David. Instead, he followed the example of his father, Joash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amaziah did not destroy the pagan shrines, and the people still offered sacrifices and burned incense there.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Amaziah was well established as king, he executed the officials who had assassinated his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, he did not kill the children of the assassins, for he obeyed the command of the Lord as written by Moses in the Book of the Law: “Parents must not be put to death for the sins of their children, nor children for the sins of their parents. Those deserving to die must be put to death for their own crimes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Amaziah also killed 10,000 Edomites in the Valley of Salt. He also conquered Sela and changed its name to Joktheel, as it is called to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day Amaziah sent messengers with this challenge to Israel’s king Jehoash, the son of Jehoahaz and grandson of Jehu: “Come and meet me in battle!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Jehoash of Israel replied to King Amaziah of Judah with this story: “Out in the Lebanon mountains, a thistle sent a message to a mighty cedar tree: ‘Give your daughter in marriage to my son.’ But just then a wild animal of Lebanon came by and stepped on the thistle, crushing it!
speaker: Narrator

text: “You have indeed defeated Edom, and you are proud of it. But be content with your victory and stay at home! Why stir up trouble that will only bring disaster on you and the people of Judah?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Amaziah refused to listen, so King Jehoash of Israel mobilized his army against King Amaziah of Judah. The two armies drew up their battle lines at Beth-shemesh in Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah was routed by the army of Israel, and its army scattered and fled for home.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Jehoash of Israel captured Judah’s king, Amaziah son of Joash and grandson of Ahaziah, at Beth-shemesh. Then he marched to Jerusalem, where he demolished 600 feet of Jerusalem’s wall, from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carried off all the gold and silver and all the articles from the Temple of the Lord. He also seized the treasures from the royal palace, along with hostages, and then returned to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Jehoash’s reign and everything he did, including the extent of his power and his war with King Amaziah of Judah, are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehoash died, he was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel. And his son Jeroboam II became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Amaziah of Judah lived for fifteen years after the death of King Jehoash of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Amaziah’s reign are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a conspiracy against Amaziah’s life in Jerusalem, and he fled to Lachish. But his enemies sent assassins after him, and they killed him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought his body back to Jerusalem on a horse, and he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of Judah had crowned Amaziah’s sixteen-year-old son, Uzziah, as king in place of his father, Amaziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: After his father’s death, Uzziah rebuilt the town of Elath and restored it to Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam II, the son of Jehoash, began to rule over Israel in the fifteenth year of King Amaziah’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Samaria forty-one years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the Lord’s sight. He refused to turn from the sins that Jeroboam son of Nebat had led Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam II recovered the territories of Israel between Lebo-hamath and the Dead Sea, just as the Lord, the God of Israel, had promised through Jonah son of Amittai, the prophet from Gath-hepher.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord saw the bitter suffering of everyone in Israel, and that there was no one in Israel, slave or free, to help them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because the Lord had not said he would blot out the name of Israel completely, he used Jeroboam II, the son of Jehoash, to save them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in the reign of Jeroboam II and everything he did—including the extent of his power, his wars, and how he recovered for Israel both Damascus and Hamath, which had belonged to Judah—are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jeroboam II died, he was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel. Then his son Zechariah became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Uzziah son of Amaziah began to rule over Judah in the twenty-seventh year of the reign of King Jeroboam II of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was sixteen years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem fifty-two years. His mother was Jecoliah from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight, just as his father, Amaziah, had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did not destroy the pagan shrines, and the people still offered sacrifices and burned incense there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord struck the king with leprosy, which lasted until the day he died. He lived in isolation in a separate house. The king’s son Jotham was put in charge of the royal palace, and he governed the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Uzziah’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Uzziah died, he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. And his son Jotham became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zechariah son of Jeroboam II began to rule over Israel in the thirty-eighth year of King Uzziah’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Samaria six months.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zechariah did what was evil in the Lord’s sight, as his ancestors had done. He refused to turn from the sins that Jeroboam son of Nebat had led Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shallum son of Jabesh conspired against Zechariah, assassinated him in public, and became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Zechariah’s reign are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord’s message to Jehu came true: “Your descendants will be kings of Israel down to the fourth generation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum son of Jabesh began to rule over Israel in the thirty-ninth year of King Uzziah’s reign in Judah. Shallum reigned in Samaria only one month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Menahem son of Gadi went to Samaria from Tirzah and assassinated him, and he became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Shallum’s reign, including his conspiracy, are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Menahem destroyed the town of Tappuah and all the surrounding countryside as far as Tirzah, because its citizens refused to surrender the town. He killed the entire population and ripped open the pregnant women.
speaker: Narrator

text: Menahem son of Gadi began to rule over Israel in the thirty-ninth year of King Uzziah’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Samaria ten years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Menahem did what was evil in the Lord’s sight. During his entire reign, he refused to turn from the sins that Jeroboam son of Nebat had led Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria invaded the land. But Menahem paid him thirty-seven tons of silver to gain his support in tightening his grip on royal power.
speaker: Narrator

text: Menahem extorted the money from the rich of Israel, demanding that each of them pay fifty pieces of silver to the king of Assyria. So the king of Assyria turned from attacking Israel and did not stay in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Menahem’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Menahem died, his son Pekahiah became the next king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pekahiah son of Menahem began to rule over Israel in the fiftieth year of King Uzziah’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Samaria two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pekahiah did what was evil in the Lord’s sight. He refused to turn from the sins that Jeroboam son of Nebat had led Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pekah son of Remaliah, the commander of Pekahiah’s army, conspired against him. With fifty men from Gilead, Pekah assassinated the king, along with Argob and Arieh, in the citadel of the palace at Samaria. And Pekah reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Pekahiah’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pekah son of Remaliah began to rule over Israel in the fifty-second year of King Uzziah’s reign in Judah. He reigned in Samaria twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pekah did what was evil in the Lord’s sight. He refused to turn from the sins that Jeroboam son of Nebat had led Israel to commit.
speaker: Narrator

text: During Pekah’s reign, King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria attacked Israel again, and he captured the towns of Ijon, Abel-beth-maacah, Janoah, Kedesh, and Hazor. He also conquered the regions of Gilead, Galilee, and all of Naphtali, and he took the people to Assyria as captives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hoshea son of Elah conspired against Pekah and assassinated him. He began to rule over Israel in the twentieth year of Jotham son of Uzziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Pekah’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jotham son of Uzziah began to rule over Judah in the second year of King Pekah’s reign in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem sixteen years. His mother was Jerusha, the daughter of Zadok.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jotham did what was pleasing in the Lord’s sight. He did everything his father, Uzziah, had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did not destroy the pagan shrines, and the people still offered sacrifices and burned incense there. He rebuilt the upper gate of the Temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the events in Jotham’s reign and everything he did are recorded in The Book of the History of the Kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days the Lord began to send King Rezin of Aram and King Pekah of Israel to attack Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jotham died, he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. And his son Ahaz became the next king.
speaker: Narrator
